data.text: Contents

Paediatric Samples ................................................................................................... 11  Unrepeatable Samples ............................................................................................. 11  Action to be taken when samples are unlabelled .................................................. 12  Sample is inadequately labelled but the request form is acceptable ................... 12  Sample is adequately labelled but the form is not filled out correctly or not clear13  Surname on sample and form do not match .......................................................... 13  Surname on form and sample match, but does not match Win path ................... 13  Unique identifier incorrect or not given but all other details correct ................. 13  Date of birth different on sample and form........................................................... 14  Training Requirements ............................................................................................. 14
Introduction

Clinical Governance demands that a sample must be uniquely labelled and uniquely associated with a test request. The information associated with a specimen must match the information on the accompanying request form. Both the specimen and the request form must fulfil a minimum set of criteria to enable safe practise as set out by accreditation bodies within Pathology.

This document details the requirements for the correct sample and request form labelling for all requests received within Blood Sciences (Biochemistry, Haematology and Immunology). Samples from other departments such as Blood Transfusion must be referred to the relevant members of staff in those departments.

In the interests of patient safety and diagnostic management, both the specimen and the request form must contain an adequate amount of information. Any specimen or request form that does not contain these essential criteria will result in samples being rejected, as their acceptance may put patients at risk.
The purpose of this document is to provide a standardised approach across the Trust to ensure that Patient samples are received into the Blood Sciences Laboratory in an acceptable manner.
It will ensure that blood requests are made appropriately and that both the request forms and the samples contain the necessary information to ensure safe practise and good governance.
Scope

This policy applies to any person within the Trust who makes a blood request, takes a blood/CSF/urine/other fluid sample, and/or labels the specimens. It also acts as an acceptance policy for the laboratory to ensure consistent and safe practice.
Definitions
For the purpose of this document Blood Sciences refers to Biochemistry, Haematology and Immunology.

table_items.text: A collective term for the pathology disciplines of Biochemistry, Haematology and Immunology.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The responsibility of ensuring that the form carries the correct information such as correct tests rests with the requesting clinician.

The responsibility of ensuring that all of the correct and sufficient patient information is on the request form and that it matches the sample container rests with the phlebotomist to ensure that all of this information is provided prior to venepuncture.
The responsibility that the specimen is adequately labelled rests with the person labelling the sample.

It is the responsibility of Specimen Reception to ensure that the specimen and request form they receive matches and carries the criteria as set out in this standard operating procedure. If there is conflicting information the sample may be rejected, although this may not apply to unrepeatable specimens.

Laboratory staff should not operate outside this policy therefore non-compliant forms or samples should not be accepted. This can only be over-ruled by the Head of Department of the specific department or a senior member of staff in Blood Sciences.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of the individual.
Form and sample identification acceptance process
Information on request forms
5.1.2 The following information is essential on a request form to ensure patient safety:

table_items.text: The patient's unique identifier (NHS, Hospital, Trauma, or GU number) should be used with at least 2 of the following: First name, or baby (male/female infant) or twin 1, 2 Surname Date of BirthNHS number where available must be inputted
The patient's unique identifier (NHS, Hospital, or GU number) should be used with at least 2 of the following: First name Surname Date of Birth NHS number where available must be inputted
The following should also be recorded: Date and time collection Requesting Clinician Area of request (ward, Outpatient) Clinical details Tests requested
The following should also be recorded: Date and time collection Requesting Clinician Area of request (GP Location) Address of the patient Clinical details Tests requested

data.text: It is the responsibility of the phlebotomist to ensure that all of this information is provided prior to venepuncture.
If there is insufficient information where appropriate a doctor or nurse should be consulted, or the patient must be asked to provide further details.
The date and time of venepuncture must be added on the request form.
Hand written amendments to electronic requests and additional pieces of papers such as post it notes will not be accepted.
Information on samples
The following information is essential on a sample:

table_items.text: The patient's unique identifier (NHS, Hospital, Trauma, or GU number) should be used with at least 2 of the following: First name, or baby (male/female infant) or twin 1, 2 Surname Date of Birth
The patient's unique identifier (NHS, Hospital, or GU number) should be used with at least 2 of the following: First name Surname Date of Birth

data.text: If labels are used they must not be placed over other printed labels, and they should leave the sample visible for laboratory staff to see.
If hand written the details should be clear and legible.
Sample and form information
Information Required for Sample Acceptance
To ensure a sample is accepted and processed by the laboratory in a timely fashion it is essential that all of the information set out in section 7 is completed.
Inaccurate or incomplete information will possibly result in a sample being rejected thereby delaying patient care and may lead to repeat venepuncture.
The sample will be rejected if there is ambiguity over the patient name, unique identifier and date of birth due to typographical errors.
Electronic requesting

Requesting tests electronically is the preferred method for the laboratory and will ensure that the correct tests are requested and analysed. It is essential that the correct requestor, correct location and correct patient are selected.

If paper requesting is essential then it is important to write clearly and legibly using a proper request forms not the printout of the order-commas request. Illegible forms will result in tests not being requested or the wrong test.
Clinical details
Appropriate and useful clinical details must always be given.
Clinical details aid in test interpretation and where appropriate will lead to further tests being added to aid in clinical diagnosis.
Clinical details are also essential for any referral test and on occasions the referral hospital will reject samples unless sufficient information is provided.
Rejected samples

Due to the number of samples processed within the laboratory it is not possible to contact the requestor if a sample is rejected. It is the responsibility of the requestor to review the request for any explanatory comments if sample or test is rejected.
Laboratory acceptance requirements
Biochemistry Sample Integrity

Unseparated Chemistry samples must be received by the laboratory within 12 hours of venepuncture. If samples are greater than 12 hours old, all tests should be booked in and the samples and request forms handed to a senior BMS in Biochemistry notifying them that they are old.

If unseparated samples are >24 hours old, a pop up box should appear in Win path. Check the dates and times to ensure that they are truly >24 hours old then book in all tests and hand the samples and request forms to a senior BMS in Biochemistry notifying them that they are >24 hours old.
Biochemistry to follow section in BS-CLIN-GU-4.
Some tests require special handling which is indicated in the Pathology Clinical User Guide.
Some tests may not be available if the sample is haemolysed, lip emic or icteric. This is assay dependent and will be indicated on the final report.
Coagulation sample integrity

If samples are >24 hours old, a pop up box should appear in Win path. Check the dates and times to ensure that they are truly >24 hours old then book in all tests and hand the samples and request forms to a senior BMS in Coagulation notifying them that they are >24 hours old.
Grossly haemolysed samples will be rejected. SHR Regret coagulation sample received haemolysed. Unsuitable for testing.
Clotted samples will be rejected. CC Regret sample for coagulation tests received clotted.

Samples that are 10% over or under filled will be analysed and the following comments added: SUC Regret coagulation sample tube received under filled giving incorrect blood/citrate ratio. Please interpret with caution. Suggest repeat. SOC Regret coagulation sample tube received over filled giving incorrect blood/citrate ratio. Please interpret with caution. Suggest repeat.

Samples that are significantly under or over filled will not be analysed and the following comments added: SUR Regret coagulation sample tube under filled giving incorrect blood/citrate ratio. Unsuitable for testing. SOR Regret coagulation sample tube over filled giving incorrect blood/citrate ratio. Unsuitable for testing.
Haematology sample integrity

If samples are >24 hours old, a pop up box should appear in Win path. Check the dates and times to ensure that they are truly >24 hours old then book in all tests and hand the samples and request forms to a senior BMS in Haematology notifying them that they are >24 hours old.
Immunology sample integrity
Most tests can be run on clotted samples up to 2 weeks post venepuncture.
However, some tests need to be separated and frozen within a few hours of the sample being taken (see Pathology Clinical User Guide for information).
Grossly haemolysed or lipaemic samples may be unsuitable for some Immunology assays. This will be indicated on the final report.
All departments
If a sample is received in the wrong bottle type then Pathology Specimen Reception should add the appropriate test code as follows:

table_items.text: No sample received for coagulation tests. Please supply citrate sample.
No sample received for FBC/ESR. Please supply 4ml EDTA sample.
No sample for PTH, please supply a separate EDTA sample for Biochemistry.
No sample received for the following Biochemistry Tests.
No sample for Trace Metal sample.
No sample received for Urine PCR.
No tests have been requested or unable to interpret what tests are required. Please contact the laboratory. Biochemistry and Immunology samples will be stored for 1 week.

data.text: If no sample has been received for Biochemistry or Immunology then use either NSRS or NSRI, then list the tests that have been requested.

If a sample is received and no tests are requested then add a ‘no tests requested' code, NOT. Sample should then be centrifuged if appropriate and stored with the spares. Samples will be kept for 1 week.

If a sample is received and it is not clear what tests are required then a reasonable attempt must be made to find out what tests may be needed by liaising with clinical staff, or contacting the requestor. If the tests can still not be deciphered then add a ‘no tests requested' code, NOT. Sample should then be centrifuged if appropriate and stored with the spares. Samples will be kept for 1 week.
Paediatric samples
Paediatric samples should follow the same criteria set out in section  However, paediatric samples are often difficult to collect, and often precious samples.

If a paediatric sample is received missing some key identification data, then the sample should be booked in if possible, and handed to the relevant department for the senior member of staff to make a decision. If the sample cannot be booked in then the sample should be handed directly to the senior member of staff to action as appropriate.
If there is no available member of staff then the sample should be centrifuged if appropriate and handed to a member of staff as soon as possible.
Unrepeatable samples
There are a number of samples that are classified as unrepeatable:
Bone marrow aspirates;
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) ;
Pleural fluid;
Post mortem samples;
Specific dynamic function tests;
Timed blood samples for tryptic.
If these do not meet all of the identification requirements the Senior BMS should be notified to make their best effort to contact the requestor to obtain all of the relevant details.
These samples should not be stored, rejected or discarded until the tests needed are conducted.

When these requests do not meet the identification requirements the requestor must take full ownership, and the details of this should be recorded by the Senior BMS in Win path so they are visible in the viewing software (e.g. MEHT review, Lorenzo).
If a Senior BMS is unable to contact the requestor and confirm the requesting Consultant, who if unavailable, they should bring it to the relevant Head of Departments attention.
Action to be taken when samples are unlabelled
When a sample is unlabelled with a completed request form, the sample should be booked in and the appropriate test code added which states that the sample is unlabelled and cannot be processed:

table_items.text: Unlabelled sample. Unable to process for Biochemistry.
Unlabelled sample. Unable to process for Haematology.
Unlabelled sample. Unable to process for fluoride sample.

data.text: Sample is inadequately labelled but the request form is acceptable

When a sample is inadequately labelled with a completed request form, the sample should be booked in and the test code added, which states that the sample is inadequately labelled and cannot be processed.

table_items.text: Form inadequately labelled. Patient identification taken from sample. Please interpret with caution.
Inadequate patient identification on fluoride sample. A minimum of 3 points of ID required for processing.
Inadequate patient information on sample for UPCR. A minimum of 3 items of identification are required for sample to be processed.
Inadequate patient identification on Immunology sample. A minimum of three points of ID required for processing.
Inadequate patient identification on Haematology sample A minimum of three points of ID required for processing.
Inadequate patient identification on Coagulation sample. A minimum of three points of ID required for processing.
Inadequate patient identification on Biochemistry sample. A minimum of three points of ID required for processing.

data.text: Sample is adequately labelled but the form is not filled out
correctly or not clear
If possible the requestor should be contacted.
If the details on the form can be verified by the sample then the test code INLF should be added.
If the demographics on the sample cannot verify the demographics on the form then book the sample in as inadequate patient identification (INAB/INAH/INAI).
No test should be assumed.

If the sample is correctly labelled but the tests are not clear then it is important to attempt to find out what tests are requested by liaising with Pathology Clinical staff, or the requestor. If the test is still not clear the following code can be used:

table_items.text: No tests have been requested or unable to interpret what tests are required. Please contact the laboratory. Biochemistry and Immunology samples will be stored for 1 week.

data.text: Surname on sample and form do not match

The patient's surname should be checked on Lorenzo to establish which is correct. If the discrepancy is due to a maiden/married name change then this should be verified on Lorenzo and the sample accepted. Detail any changes in Win path.
Surname on form and sample match, but does not match Win path
Lorenzo should first be checked in case a maiden/married name has changed.
If Lorenzo is also wrong, bring to the attention of a senior as the requestor may need to be contacted to confirm. Add WDEM comment.
Unique identifier incorrect or not given but all other details correct

If the hospital number or NHS number does not yield the patient as detailed but all other information is correct then the sample can be processed by excluding the unique identifier and adding a comment in Win path (@MNHS NHS number missing from request form). However, if the unique identifier belongs to another patient then the sample must be rejected.
Date of birth different on sample and form
Lorenzo must be checked to determine what the correct DOB is.
If the days date has been used on the form but is correct on the sample then the sample can be accepted, and the form accepted and initialled.
If the DOB is correct on the form and the days date has been used on the sample, the DOB must be confirmed and there must be another 3 points of identification.
If there are 3 points of identification then the sample can be accepted with WDEM comment added.
If there are not 3 points of identification then the sample must be rejected by adding the code INAB/INAH/INAI/INU as appropriate, and the sample repeated.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Quality Lead per discipline, Quality manager
Quality Lead per discipline, Quality manager

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the discipline group leads then referred to Broomfield Hospital Pathology Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Blood Sciences Department of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References
Patient sample and request form identification criteria, Council of the Institute of Biomedical Science (IBMS 2000)
Medical laboratories-requirements for quality and competence (ISO15189:2012)
